**Lifecycle Planning**

Chapter 7 of Steve McConnell&#39;s book focuses on the different software development lifecycles and it shows how each and one of them provide different benefits to de delivery process.

According to the author, every software development effort goes through this called _lifecycle_, which consists of all the activities between the time that the first version of a system begins life as a gleam in someone&#39;s eye and the time that the latest version finally takes its last breath on the last customer&#39;s machine.

The main function of a lifecycle model is to establish the order in which a project specifies, prototypes, designs, implements, reviews, tests, and performs its other activities. It establishes the criteria that you use to determine whether to proceed from one task to the next. The most familiar lifecycle model is the well-known waterfall lifecycle model, which has some equally well-known weaknesses. Other lifecycle models are

available, and in many cases, they are better choices for rapid development than the waterfall model is.

Here&#39;s a brief map that shows an overview of the different approaches the author suggests:

 ![](data:image/*;base64,)

As mentioned before, the different approaches, offer different pros and cons. The granddaddy of all lifecycle models is the _waterfall_ model. Although it has many problems, it serves as the basis for other, more effective lifecycle models, so it&#39;s presented first in this chapter. In the waterfall model, a project progresses through an orderly sequence of steps from the initial software concept through system testing. The project holds a review at the end of each phase to determine whether it is ready to advance to the next phase. The waterfall model is document driven, which means that the main work products that are carried from phase to phase are documents. In the pure waterfall model, the phases are also discontinuous, hence they do not overlap.

- _Code-and-Fix:_

The code-and-fix model is a model that is seldom useful, but it is nonetheless common, so I&#39;d like to discuss it. If you haven&#39;t explicitly chosen another lifecycle model, you&#39;re probably using code-and-fix by default. If you haven&#39;t done much project planning, you&#39;re undoubtedly using code-and-fix. Combined with a short schedule, code-and-fix gives rise to the code-like-hell approach described earlier. When you use the code-and-fix model, you start with a general idea of what you want to build. You might have a formal specification, or you might not.

You then use whatever combination of informal design, code, debug, and test methodologies suits you until you have a product that&#39;s ready to release.



- _Spiral_:

At the other end of the sophistication scale from the code-and-fix model is the spiral model. The spiral model is a risk-oriented lifecycle model that breaks a software project up into mini-projects. Each mini-project addresses

one or more major risks until all the major risks have been addressed. The concept of &quot;risk&quot; is broadly defined in this context, and it can refer to poorly understood requirements, poorly understood architecture, potential performance problems, problems in the underlying technology, and so on. After the major risks have all been addressed, the spiral model terminates as a waterfall lifecycle model would.

Each iteration involves the six steps shown in bold on die outer edges of the spiral:

1. Determine objectives, alternatives, and constraints
2. Identify and resolve risks
3. Evaluate alternatives
4. Develop the deliverables for that iteration, and verify that they
5. are correct
6. Plan the next iteration
7. Commit to an approach for the next iteration (if you decide to
8. have one)

In the spiral model, the early iterations are the cheapest. You spend less developing the concept of operation than you do developing the requirements, and less developing the requirements than you do developing the design, implementing the product, and testing it.



- _Modified Waterfalls:_

The activities identified in the pure waterfall model are intrinsic to software development. You can&#39;t avoid them. You must come up with a software concept somehow, and you must get requirements from somewhere. You don&#39;t have to use the waterfall lifecycle model to gather requirements, but you do have to use something. Likewise, you can&#39;t avoid having an architecture, design, or code. In this approach, the author suggests the following:

1. Sashimi (Waterfall with Overlapping Phases): The traditional waterfall model allows for minimal overlapping between phases at the end-of-phase review. This model suggests a stronger degree of overlap.



1. Waterfall with Subprojects: Another problem with the pure waterfall model from a rapid development point of view is that you&#39;re supposed to be completely done with architectural design before you begin detailed design, and you&#39;re supposed to be completely done with detailed design before you begin coding and debugging. The main risk with this approach is unforeseen interdependences. You can partly account for that by eliminating dependencies at architecture time or waiting until after detailed-design time to break the project into subprojects.



1. Waterfall with Risk Reduction: The risk-reduction preamble to the waterfall lifecycle isn&#39;t limited to requirements. You could use it to reduce architectural risk or any other risk to the project. If the product depends on developing a high-risk nucleus to the system, you might use a risk-reduction cycle to fully develop the high-risk nucleus before you commit to a full-scale project.

- _Evolutionary Prototyping:_

Evolutionary prototyping is a lifecycle model in which you develop the system concept as you move through the project. Usually you begin by developing the most visible aspects of the system. You demonstrate that part of the system to the customer and then continue to develop die prototype based on the feedback you receive.



- Staged Delivery:

The staged-delivery model is another lifecycle model in which you show software to the customer in successively refined stages. Unlike the evolutionary prototyping model, when you use staged delivery, you know exactly what you&#39;re going to build when you set out to build it. What makes the staged delivery model distinctive is that you don&#39;t deliver the software at the end of the project in one fell swoop.



- Design-to-Schedule:

The design-to-schedule lifecycle model is like the staged-release lifecycle model in that you plan to develop the product in successive stages. The difference is that you don&#39;t necessarily know at the outset that you&#39;ll ever make it to the last release. You might have five stages planned but only make it to the third stage because you have an immovable deadline.



- Evolutionary Delivery:

Evolutionary delivery is a lifecycle model that straddles the ground between evolutionary prototyping and staged delivery. You develop a version of your product, show it to your customer, and refine the product based on customer feedback. How much evolutionary delivery looks like evolutionary prototyping really depends on the extent to which you plan to accommodate customer requests. If you plan to accommodate most requests, evolutionary delivery will look a lot like evolutionary prototyping.



- Design-to-Tools:

The idea behind the design-to-tools model is that you put a capability into your product only if it&#39;s directly supported by existing software tools. If it isn&#39;t supported, you leave it out. By &quot;tools,&quot; I mean code and class libraries, code generators, rapid-development languages, and other software tools that dramatically reduce implementation time.



- Commercial Off-the-Shelf Software:

One alternative that is sometimes overlooked in the excitement surround ing a new system is the option to buy software off the shelf. Off-the-shelf software will rarely satisfy all your needs. Custom software probably won&#39;t turn out to match your mental vision of the ideal software. Comparisons between custom-built software and off the-shelf software tend to compare the actual off-the-shelf software to the idealized custom-built software. However, when you build your own software, you must make design, cost, and schedule concessions.

At the end of the line different projects have different needs, even if they all need to be developed as quickly as possible. The software lifecycle models previously shown provide you with a full range of choices. Which one is fastest? There is no such thing as a &quot;_rapid-development lifecycle model_&quot; because the most effective model depends on the context in which it&#39;s used. Certain lifecycle models are sometimes touted as being more rapid

than others, but each one will be fastest in some situations, slowest in others. A lifecycle model that often works well can work poorly if misapplied.

**Motivation, Teamwork and Team Structure**

Chapter 11 of the Steve McConnell&#39;s book talks a lot about how the three aspects of motivation take place within organizations with managers and developers. They talk about morale and job satisfaction and everything begins with a case study in which a manager that destroys motivation on a leader and subsequently on his employees, at the end of the chapter, there&#39;s another case study that talks about the complete opposite situation with Microsoft culture and the practices they perform to constantly keep their employees with high morale.

The author mentions that between developers and managers. If you&#39;re a manager and you try to motivate your developers the same way that you would like to be motivated, you &#39;re likely to fail. Developers care little about the responsibility or recognition that would motivate you. If you want to motivate developers, emphasize technical challenges, autonomy, the chance to learn and use new skills, and career planning and respect their personal lives.

During the chapter, there are a lot of explanations on Motivation Factors such as:

- Achievements

Software developers like to work. The best way to motivate developers is to provide an environment that makes it easy for them to focus on what they like doing most, which is developing software.

- Possibility of Growth

One of the most exciting aspects of being a software developer is working in a field that is constantly changing. You must learn something every day just to stay current, and half of what you need to know to do your job today will be out of date 3 years from now. Considering the nature of the industry developers have chosen to work in, it isn&#39;t surprising that they are motivated by possibilities for growth.

- Work Itself

Characteristics that contribute to how meaningful people find their work to be:

-
  - Skill variety.
  - Task identity.
  - Task significance.
  - Autonomy.
  - Job feedback.
- The personal life of the employees

The motivational impact of a developer&#39;s personal life is likely to be the hardest motivational factor for a manager to understand.

In another part of the chapter there it is also mentioned about the different morale killers such as:

- Hygiene Factors
- Management manipulation
- Excessive schedule pressure.
- Lack of appreciation for development&#39;s efforts
- Inappropriate involvement of technically inept management
- Not involving developers in decisions that affect them.
- Productivity barriers.
- Low quality.
- Heavy-handed motivation campaigns

At the end of the day motivation comes from teams and/or organizations who treat their employees with different considerations and it is worth mentioning that &quot;money&quot; or &quot;souvenirs&quot; aren&#39;t always the best approach.

In general terms the following chapter 12

# th
 talks about teamwork, a crucial part in an organization to succeed. Some of the important points that caught my attention were that Teamwork can come into play on software projects on any number of specific tasks such as:
- Developing and reviewing the project&#39;s requirements.
- Developing the project&#39;s architecture and the design guidelines that will be used by the whole project.
- Defining aspects of the technical environment that will be used on the project (including the programming languages, compilers, source-code libraries, code generators, editors, and version-control tools).
- Developing coding standards that will be used by the whole project.
- Coordinating work on related pieces of a project (including defining interfaces between subsystems, modules, and classes).
- Designing difficult parts of the system.
- Reviewing individual developers&#39; designs and code.
- Debugging difficult parts of the system.
- Testing of requirements, design, and code.
- Auditing a project&#39;s progress.
- Maintaining software once it has been built (including responding to maintenance requests and making emergency fixes).

They talk about the fact that a highly cohesive team will lock onto a shared vision that is at odds with the organization&#39;s objectives. In this case, the team might get a lot of work done, but not the kind of work the organization needs. To be productive, a cohesive group needs to have a focus compatible with the organization they are a part of.

It is also mentioned how smart companies reinforce the team&#39;s sense of identity by providing team T-shirts, notepads, mugs, and other paraphernalia that validate the team as a legitimate entity.

In many cases team members allow their sense of team identity to overshadow their identities as individuals. They derive satisfaction from the team&#39;s accomplishments. They see the common goal as more important than their personal agendas.

For rapid development, team members need to be chosen based on who has the competencies that are currently needed. Three kinds of competencies are important:

- Specific technical skills application area, platform, methodologies, and programming language.
- A strong desire to contribute.
- Specific collaboration skills required to work effectively with others.

Members of cohesive teams stay in touch with each other constantly. They are careful to see that everyone understands when they speak, and their communication is aided by the fact that they share a common vision and sense of identity. Amish barn raisers communicate efficiently during a barn raising because they live in a tight-knit community and nearly all of them have been through barn raisings before. They are able to communicate precise meanings with a few words or gestures because they have already established a baseline of mutual understanding.

In the last part of the chapter 12, the author states several points on _why teams fail_ and they are:

- Lack of common vision.
- Lack of identity.
- Lack of recognition.
- Productivity roadblocks.
- Ineffective communication.
- Lack of trust.
- Problem personnel.

And on the opposite side some of the reasons to keep teams together are these facts:

- Higher productivity.
- Lower startup costs.
- Lower risk of personnel problems.
- Less turnover.
- The idleness questions.

The example the author gives at the beginning of the chapter with those _Amish Farmers_ represents a well-structured team and focuses its attention on how the best scenario for current teams would be. They are a good model of the perfect, jelled team. But that team didn&#39;t form overnight. Those farmers had been together for years, and their families had been together for years before that. You can&#39;t expect performance as dramatic as raising a barn in a single day from a temporary team. That kind of productivity comes only from permanent teams.

At last but not least, chapter 13

# th
 describes the primary considerations in organizing a rapid development team and lays out several models of team structure. It concludes with a discussion of one of the most nettlesome team- structure issues: the relationship between project managers and technical leads.

The chapter shows us the case study for a home run project and how it was the lack of communication that ended up having the product delivered in form and shape but really late, the general idea here is that the first consideration in organizing a team is to determine the team&#39;s broad objective by having:

- Problem resolution
- Creativity
- Tactical execution

Once you&#39;ve established the broad objective, you choose a team structure that matches it. As mentioned before the users in the case study had described exactly what they wanted, and the team really just needed to create and execute a plan for implementing it. Bill got some bad advice from Randy, who should have identified the primary goal of the team as tactical execution. The users were more interested in getting a timely upgrade than they were in creative solutions. The effect of the bad advice was predictable: organized for creativity, the team came up with a highly creative solution but didn&#39;t execute their plan efficiently. They weren&#39;t organized for that.

Which Kind of Team Is Best for Rapid Development? A key to organizing a team for rapid development is understanding that there is no single team structure that achieves the maximum development speed on every project. There&#39;s no such thing as a single best _&quot;rapid-development team structure&quot;_ because the most effective structure depends on the context

As a big part of the chapter it can be concluded that the team models shown, vary depending on the context of each organization and required task, these are as follows:

- Business Team
- Chief-Programmer Team
- Skunkworks Team
- Feature Team
- Search-and-Rescue Team
- SWAT Team
- Professional Athletic Team
- Large Teams
